Once upon a time Iran was working towards democracy and loved Americans. It had even elected, fairly democratically, a fellow named Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh. Unfortunately Dr. Mossadegh had the weird idea that the oil under Iran's soil belonged to Iran and he nationalized the oil of Iran. That made Winston Churchill very, very, very angry because he thought that Iran's oil belonged to British Petroleum and Churchill also had a problem with the color of Mossadegh's skin. Churchill seethed and seethed and tried to get Harry Truman to put the kibosh on Mossadegh but Truman kind of liked Mossadegh and thought he was a jolly guy. So Churchill just seethed and sulked and seethed and sulked and then Dwight D. Eisenhower got elected president.
 
 Well, Ike and Winnie were old buddies from WWII so Ike said, "Sure, Winnie, let's do it!" and he sent in Kermit Roosevelt, head of the fledgling organization to be later known as the CIA. Kermit was also a grandson of Teddy Roosevelt, for the record, and he really thought he was a dapper, cavalier kind of dude. Kermit went into Iran and essentially pulled off a bloodless coup and deposed Mossadegh and the US of A installed wienie-boy Mohammad Reza Pahlavi as shah and made sure the Iranians were cowed into bowing down before the sissy boy who followed US orders. The poor, trusting Iranians were utterly taken by surprise by the dirty, down and low tricks of the United States. They believed that Americans were decent and trustworthy at that point. Boy! Were they fooled!
 
 Things certainly were not happy for the Iranians under the thumb of the Shah and the hidden American force that kept him in place. Meanwhile, a certain Ayatollah Ruhollah Musavi Khomeini (who was very popular with the Iranians) was threatened with execution but then exiled to France and the hopes of Iranians with him.
 
 When the time was ripe for him to Iran to depose the weakened Shah, he was a very, very, very angry Ayatollah and the Iranians were a very, very, very angry people because it was no fun under the thumb of the Shah and the hidden U.S. force that kept him in place. They sure didn't love Americans any more and they sure didn't trust them, the Americans. Fool me once, you know how it goes.
 
 And then, the latest model of wienie-boys, BoyWonder Bush, adds fuel to the fire--just when Iran was rethinking its position regarding the US, especially since the US had been nice enough to remove Iran's Number One Concern in the Middle East Saddam Hussein--and declared that Iran was part of the three-part axis of evil. Talk about your pure stupidity! Or, maybe it was just part of Bushy's and the Neo-Conmen's plans to turn the Middle East into a raging fire. Maybe that's their divine plan.

I think it has more to do with the historical status of europe and also to do with the positioning of the Greenwich meridian. In any case the west has always been a fairly vague term.
I'll definitely agree with that too. The whole thing on Jerusalem being the center of the world was somewhat of a religious/historical/guess thing I was testing the waters with.

Oh dear, Judeau, I suppose you haven't had any of your shots, have you?
 
 The rest of you, do you have anything contagious, measles, mumps, etc.? Stay away from Judeau.

Oh dear, Judeau, I suppose you haven't had any of your shots, have you?
 
 The rest of you, do you have anything contagious, measles, mumps, etc.? Stay away from Judeau.

 
 Aw, no need to poke at the CSers.
Sorry, Judeau, I've attacked everyone else. I didn't want to leave you out. I'm an equal opportunity attacker.
Footnote, Judeau, the CS version of the Lord's Prayer is my favorite version. It's so delightful, I mean when one refers to the Deity as "Adorable One" . . .

Hey, it really doesn't bother me. I am very impressed that you have read/heard the CS interpretation of the Lord's Prayer and thankyou, I like it as well. Just as a side note, in church we always say a line of the Lord's Prayer as it is in the Bible (many people think we don't even use the Bible but the Bible is the basis of our teachings) and then our reader says the interpretation.
